posts.post_content:
It fits the flavor of demons a lot better than [Ob Nixilis, the Fallen](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Ob Nixilis, the Fallen), did. They feel more believable when they punish their summoner the way [Lord of the Pit](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Lord of the Pit) or [Rakdos the Defiler](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Rakdos the Defiler) do.  
  
I'd like to second the comment about MoE's posting habits. 0.5/5 for bad posting habits. It's okay not to start a word with a capital letter, even if you're excited.

I'd like to second the comment about MoE's posting habits. 0.5/5 for bad posting habits. It's okay not to start a word with a capital letter, even if you're excited.

Posted By: Haliax (1/31/2010 1:19:21 AM)
Rating:

posts.post_content: I'll start by saying the card is really cool and has lots of potential, but how can any of you sit around and call it "mythic worthy". This rarity of Mythic status is a corporate creation to increase their profits. If they still had the old system where rare cards were the top of the heap we would still see cards that are just as powerful and they would be more affordable. They now use this mythic rarity to create even more chase cards so that collectors and players will be forced to buy more boosters in order to create competitive decks. I'm sure you are all aware of this but how is that you justify supporting their decision to exploit players on their own site. You may as well just write "Hurrah, Hurrah, Please continue to exploit me." But I suppose they don't need to see it in writing when they can just watch their sales increase...

Posted By: Tobolococo (3/10/2010 12:57:26 PM)
Rating:

posts.post_content:
@DonRoyale  
  
You think it's a problem this \*doesn't\* fit in jund? So you only want good red/green/black cards that make the vastly dominant archetype in the format even MORE powerful? Why on earth would you want that? This guy opens up design space for black decks where there wasn't before.  
  
This guy is simply amazing. Magic hasn't seen this exciting a black creatures since [Juzam Djinn](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Juzam Djinn), IMO. And this guy is definitely better.  
  
Saying that it dies of removal, and that your opponent can stop your ways of killing him makes him subpar is equally silly.   
  
This has been said before, but people don't seem to get it: Just because a card has \*some\* weakness doesn't make it crap.
posts.html:
@DonRoyale

You think it's a problem this *doesn't* fit in jund? So you only want good red/green/black cards that make the vastly dominant archetype in the format even MORE powerful? Why on earth would you want that? This guy opens up design space for black decks where there wasn't before.

This guy is simply amazing. Magic hasn't seen this exciting a black creatures since Juzam Djinn, IMO. And this guy is definitely better.

Saying that it dies of removal, and that your opponent can stop your ways of killing him makes him subpar is equally silly.

This has been said before, but people don't seem to get it: Just because a card has *some* weakness doesn't make it crap.

Posted By: .Fighter. (1/30/2010 12:16:09 PM)
Rating:

posts.post_content:
The fact that this is a demon really hurts with [Baneslayer Angel](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Baneslayer Angel) around to kick its \*\*\*. And while it's certainly big, it's still just a beatstick. And I hear using removal on your own guys is bad.  
  
It's a brilliant Spike design though, as it requires significant skill to play with or against it and its power level is very complicated to evaluate properly. Plus, it's flavorful, it's memorable, the flavor text is right-on, and it's totally original. As skeptical I am of its competitive viability, I have to admire its general awesomeness as a card design.
posts.html:
The fact that this is a demon really hurts with Baneslayer Angel around to kick its ***. And while it's certainly big, it's still just a beatstick. And I hear using removal on your own guys is bad.

Posted By: sir_dwar (1/30/2010 6:43:19 PM)
Rating:

posts.post_content:
I don´t see the drawback as a big problem. Getting him out on the 4th turn your opponent will do everything to remove him a fast as possible.  
He is just a too great threat to leave him on the board to long. Even if your opponent speculates with the thought that the Presecutor prevents him from loosing, he will never know if you have some sort of sacrifice Outlet like [Bone Splinters](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Bone Splinters) or any devour-creature on your hand to nullify the effect.  
  
The Presecutor adds a lot of fun and a whole dose of adrenalin to the game, making him a 5/5 to me.

Posted By: persecutor (3/30/2010 11:34:37 AM)
Rating:

posts.post_content:
4CC and can wreck your opponent in about 3 turns (\*\*\*uming you dealt some damage before casting him). Innocent Blood, Rite of Consumption, Phyrexian Tower, Culling the Weak, Cabal Therapy...black has got a hundred ways to deal with the "drawback". Still, this card is just another reason why Baneslayer probably shouldn't have been made. Maybe Wizards was foreshadowing overpowered demons with the release of an overpowered angel.  
   
This is how you design a good, but fun to play creature--you chop off a few mana symbols and replace them with drawbacks...and as we've all noticed, the two most competitively played creatures (BS and Goyf) have the first part, but not the latter.  
  
\*\*\*\*I also just wanted to mention that the Eldrazi Orb turned up 6 instances of Demon...so that may be of interest...
posts.html:
4CC and can wreck your opponent in about 3 turns (***uming you dealt some damage before casting him). Innocent Blood, Rite of Consumption, Phyrexian Tower, Culling the Weak, Cabal Therapy...black has got a hundred ways to deal with the "drawback". Still, this card is just another reason why Baneslayer probably shouldn't have been made. Maybe Wizards was foreshadowing overpowered demons with the release of an overpowered angel.

This is how you design a good, but fun to play creature--you chop off a few mana symbols and replace them with drawbacks...and as we've all noticed, the two most competitively played creatures (BS and Goyf) have the first part, but not the latter.

****I also just wanted to mention that the Eldrazi Orb turned up 6 instances of Demon...so that may be of interest...

Posted By: spectermonger (3/29/2010 9:18:07 AM)
Rating:

posts.post_content:
I've changed my vote on this guy. I used to be a big advocate. The biggest problem is that he doesn't fit the current Standard at all. The most viable decks I've seen come up to include him are MBC and BR Aggro. Vamps > MBC, and RbDW > BR Aggro.   
  
However, once Shards rotates out, I suspect Standard will get much slower than it is now, and this can mean that Persecutor may become quite viable, especially if the Eldrazi become competitive. He comes out turn 4 and bashes their face while they slowly get to their super ultimate Eldrazi gods, but once they're at 0 or negative life, they won't want to attack with that Annihilator or use All is Dust.
posts.html:
I've changed my vote on this guy. I used to be a big advocate. The biggest problem is that he doesn't fit the current Standard at all. The most viable decks I've seen come up to include him are MBC and BR Aggro. Vamps > MBC, and RbDW > BR Aggro.

However, once Shards rotates out, I suspect Standard will get much slower than it is now, and this can mean that Persecutor may become quite viable, especially if the Eldrazi become competitive. He comes out turn 4 and bashes their face while they slowly get to their super ultimate Eldrazi gods, but once they're at 0 or negative life, they won't want to attack with that Annihilator or use All is Dust.
